newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks end higher led by banks, bonds.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks end higher led by banks, bonds.

text.p: CHANGE CHANGE
NIKKEI 20443.93 -127.11 LME CASH NICKEL US$7455 -70.0
CANDLR 1.3717 LME CASH ALUM US$1399.0 -10.5
CAN 30-YR 101.40 +0.15 BRENT OCT CRUDE US$23.86 +0.29

-------------------------------------------------------------- * Toronto stocks rallied to a strong finish, led by strong bank shares * TSE also helped by bonds following release of subdued inflation data * 98.7 million shares traded
Toronto stocks rallied to a strong finish on Thursday, led by soaring bank stocks and a subdued U.S. inflation picture.
The TSE 300 Index rose 31.20 points to close at 5191.60 in heavy turnover of 98.7 million shares valued at C$1.4 billion.
Advancing stocks outpaced declines 504 to 405 with 306 issues ending flat. Canadian bonds strengthened along with U.S. treasuries on tame U.S. producer price data.
"It was the best of both worlds. Economic growth but with no inflationary pressures," said Jim Doak, senior vice-presiden of investment research at ScotiaMcLeod Inc.
The overall producer price index (PPI) rose 0.3 percent in August, but the core numbers slipped 0.1 percent. The core data excludes volatile food and energy items.
Analysts said the PPI numbers and sagging gold prices are bearish for inflation and suggest U.S. interest rates may not move higher in the short term.
On the TSE, all but one of Toronto's 14 sub-indices finished higher, led by the banks, consumer products, utilities and energy.
The lone weak sector was metals and minerals.
--- HOT STOCKS ---

* Bank stocks dominated the most-active list. Royal Bank of Canada jumped 1.05 to close at 36.20 on 2.1 million shares. The stock hit a new high of 36.25 after the bank announced plans for a huge share buyback valued at about C$1.1 billion.
* Other strong banks included Toronto-Dominion Bank, ending up 0.55 at 26.95 after reaching a new high of 27.
Bank of Montreal added 0.25 to close at 33.90.
* Among base metals, Inco Ltd sank 0.45 to close at 43.20. Inco said its 1998 target date to start open pit mining at Voisey's Bay will be a "tight" deadline to meet.
* Fairfax Financial was the top gainer, up 10 to 260.
-- Reuters Toronto Bureau (416) 941-8100
